titlePart.supplied: Speech to the El Paso Kiwanis Club

sourceDesc.p: State Birth Control Instruction Is Proposed By Margaret Sanger, Herald Post, Mar. 1, 1939 and Birth Control Need Told by Mrs. Sanger, El Paso Times, Mar. 2, 1939

doc.headNote:
Sanger addressed the Kiwanis Club of El Paso at a lunch at the Hotel Cortez. An article the next day in the El Paso Times noted that though the audience was interested, "They were not deeply stirred. After all, the subject to hardly any of them was of personal application. Theirs was only an academic interest. Either because of age or financial resources, or martial status or lack of same, they were not in situations where birth control touched their lives."
The summary of this speech was drawn from two newspapers; for Sanger's rough notes, see Margaret Sanger Microfilm S72:66.

docBody.head: State Birth Control Instruction Is Proposed By Margaret Sanger

q.p: Birth control instruction in the public health programs of the states and the Federal Government is the goal of the Birth Control Federation of America, the federation’s honorary president, Mrs. Margaret Sanger, said in El Paso today.

Mrs. Sanger, youthful and brimming with health and enthusiasm, arrived today from Tucson to pay an official visit to the El Paso Mother’s Health Center. She spoke today at the Kiwanis Club at Hotel Cortez and at the Health Center to mothers and to the board of directors.
Citing the increase of the national birth rate of "over a million a year,” she said she refused to weep crocodile tears over our falling birth rate.
She said that, "young married couples in love will have babies,” regardless of the predictions that the better class of people will not with birth control knowledge.
“They will get an economic footing and have their babies,” she said. “They want to reproduce the one they love.”

The Birth Control Federation of America now incorporates all the birth control activities and clinics in the United States under its direction, Mrs. Sanger said. She told of the increase, by 125, of the privately directed clinics, now 480 in the past two years.

“The total of 480 clinics does not include clinics operated by civic organizations in communities,” Mrs. Sanger said. “North and South Carolina have included birth control instruction in their public health programs.”

p.q: The South will lead the country in putting birth control instruction in the public health programs, Mrs. Sanger predicted.

div.head: South Sees Need
div.p: “The South sees the need in her own confines,” she said.

q.p: Birth control is not only a national but an international need, the internationally known woman said.

div.head: Crowded Nations
div.p: “Germany, Italy and Japan, the three high pressure nations, have become the danger spots to the peace of the world,” she said. “While they make their claim for more territory and colonies, they are not content to cut down their birth rate and keep their population within their national resources. They too wish to increase their population for military strength.”

q.p: She emphasized that Germany’s population in 1935 was 67,000,000, only one million less than it was in 1914, after which there was a loss of 10 million in the World War and 27,000 square miles in territory.

div.head: Talks to Kiwanians
div.p: “In other words, her present population and density is back to explosion point of 1914 which caused the World War,” Mrs. Sanger said. “There is no use asking any nation to reduce its armaments without reducing its birth rates. There has got to be an equalization of birth rates as well as of territory if we will have peace.”

q.p: Mrs. Sanger defined birth control for the Kiwanians today. She pointed out that birth control does not interfere with life.

div.p: “It is a conscious control of the birth rate by means that prevent conception,” she said. “It does not kill, does not interfere with life. It is ‘control’ and not ‘limit.’”

div.head: 150,000 Useless Deaths

q.p: The United States has not reduced its maternity mortality rate in 20 years, Mrs. Sanger said.

div.p: “A total of 150,000 mothers and infants died in 1937,” she said. “More than one-half of them could have been saved through scientific knowledge if it had been applied. The opponents of birth control must take a large share of responsibility for their deaths. The report of the Children’s Bureau, from which I got these figures, shows that where there is spacing of children in a family, there are 147 infant deaths out of 1000, when only one year apart. While 95 deaths occur in 1000 where there is two years of spacing between babies.
“Sixty-five per cent of the babies born in 1937 were in families either on relief or with incomes of less than $20 a week,” she said.

div.head: Hits Old Age Theory
div.p: “There are 13,000,000 children in families on relief, or with a total income of less than $15 a week,” she said.

“I object to the philosophy that parents have the right to have children to sustain them in their old age,” Mrs. Sanger said. “With the labor saving machines fast taking the place of man labor, by the time the children born today will be able to assist their parents, machines will have superseded those children. Their labor will not be needed. But the laws of a humane government will further advance the age of exploitation of children. Children will be kept longer in school. It is a short sighted policy of any group to encourage the birth of children in this strata of our population.”

div.head: Birth Control Need Told By Mrs. Sanger

p.supplied: Additional quotes by Sanger from the El Paso Times appear below.

div.p: "There can only be peace in the world when all nations will keep their populations within the scope of national resources," Mrs. Sanger said.
